entry.title: Managing requirements for a many-thousands contributors software
Datascience when there is no data
Digital Signal Processing Demystified
entry.summary:
Description

Want to understand the “magic" behind speech recognition, image manipulation, and data compression? The world is full of signals, and digital signal processing (DSP) allows us to interpret and manipulate them, leveraging the power of computers. Images, audio, video, temperature, tweets, anything measurable in time and/or space can be represented as a digital signal, and analyzed using DSP. Learn what DSP is, and how you can use it to look at data, and the world around you, with a new critical eye.

"DSP has a reputation of being hard to learn, but you do not need profound analytical skills or an extensive background in mathematics to grasp the fundamental concepts. If you know basic algebra, and you know what a sine wave is, you can learn the basics of DSP.

"There are some great python libraries for employing DSP. I will provide examples using Python and the SciPy package. "

  • Amy Boyl

entry.title: Fail early, fail often, fail well
entry.summary:
Description

It happens. Things go south and it's not even clear how. Your client and you can't see eye to eye, or your enthusiastic new business partner has dropped off the radar. The project you've invested weeks, months, or years into may never see the light of day.

"Failure comes in many forms and the increasing complexity of our projects and the world they operate in doesn't help. Despite our best efforts, learning the hard way is often the only way. Perhaps this is why modern startup culture has rallied around the mantra: “Fail fast. Fail early. Fail often." But I spent the better part of my career failing in freelance, agency, and startups, and the experience leads me to believe the common refrain to be lacking.

"Like gymnasts who train to fall properly, I believe we must learn to fail well.

"In this talk, I draw from my experience learning the hard way, flagging the ten easiest and most insidious mistakes one can make. Because failure is inevitable, I will also be sharing a framework for recovery that includes managing yourself, your relationships, and your reputation.

"Attendees will leave with a better sense of what NOT to do, an idea of how to cope with failure, and the knowledge that failure is inevitable and that's OK. "

  • Joshua Simmon

entry.title: How to teach git
entry.summary:
Description

Version control is a necessary piece of the python community and Git has a steep learning curve. Here is what I have learned from teaching Git to beginners, so you don't have to make the same mistakes. This talk is intended for people who already know Git and would like to teach or mentor new converts."

  • Georgia Re

entry.title: Hunting Treasures in Django
entry.summary:
Description

Django is a comprehensive web framework that provides well-defined concepts such as request, response, middleware and view that make our lives as perfectionists with deadlines much easier. What many of us are not aware of is the rich collection of utilities and tooling around these concepts that are part of the famework. Decorators, helper functions and context managers that are used internally but can make life as a developer much easier as well."

  • Sebastian Vette

entry.title: Jupyter + Pandas for an intuitive, beginner-friendly data analysis workflow
entry.summary:
Description

In this talk I'd walk through what I think are the best features of Jupyter (like magic methods, multimedia, several options for markup language, built-in documentation) and the best features of Pandas (powerful I/O, intelligent treatment of datetime) and analyze a public dataset. In this way I'd demonstrate that, as is typical of Python efforts, this is an extraordinarily lucid and beginner-friendly way to do data analysis in an open, replicable way.

"I'll also make the notebook and dataset available in advance of the talk so people can follow along. "

  • Melissa Lewi

entry.title: Using conda for development, continuous integration, and package distribution
Code review, revision and technical debt
Build a one page with Django and Angular
entry.summary:
Description

In this talk we'll be learning the ins and outs of how to develop a Single Page Application using Angular and Django."

  • José A. Hernández Rosale

entry.title: Computer Recreations or, Rediscovering the 80s for Programming Fun
entry.summary:
Description

In this talk we'll be discussing the SciAm Computer Recreations columns as a source for examples and interesting things and how to use these interesting examples to teach Computer Science."

  • Andrew Kuchlin

entry.title: Your test are bad, and you should feel... Good!
entry.summary:
Description

This talk will be about testing, why you and your team should be doing it and why it's important."

  • Chris Neugebaue
